Description: Amuletic string: consisting of a few short truncated convex bicone beads of cornelian and garnet, many discs of green glazed composition and blue glass, a blue glazed composition axe-head-shaped amulet, one spherical bead and a barrel bead of silver and one barrel bead and a frog amulet of gold. Both the gold barrel and the frog are flattened. The silver spherical bead has fallen apart into two halves. Several of the cornelian beads and some of the glass beads now carry a silver deposit probably because they were in contact with the silver beads on the string or else with another silver object now completely corroded away.
Curator's comments: Cemetery F dated by Loat, to the Sixth Dynasty, but the axe-head-shaped amulet is exclusively First Intermediate Period in date: G. Brunton, 'Qau and Badari' II (London, 1927-30), 11, pl.XCIX, type 73P. Sporadic examples of glass beads are known from the Old Kingdom, see A. Lucas, ‘Ancient Egyptian Materials and Industries’, 4th ed. (London, 1962), 180, although this material was not produced in any quantity until the time of the New Kingdom. Bibliography: W. L. S. Loat in 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 9 (1923), 161-3, published E.H. Ayrton's excavations in 1908-9 at Cemetery E, Abydos, from the records available. The account stops at no. 246: tomb 247 is not mentioned.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (216)
